abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the National
            Agricultural Services Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as substantial, bank performance as satisfactory, and
            borrower performance as satisfactory. The main lessons
            learned from this project include: 1) Political buy in of
            Government into a proposed far fetching privatization is an
            absolute necessity for its successful implementation. 2)
            Reform is a long-term process that spans the life of more
            than one project and requires the adoption of an agreed
            approach by all concerned parties. 3) Working through
            existing national directorates instead of project units, and
            using civil servants instead of contractual personnel for
            project implementation strengthens Government's
            capacity and ownership. 4) The pilot project was based on a
            successful pilot program for USAID to train civil servants
            and motivate them in joining the private sector. The scaling
            up within the project failed as only few civil servants left
            as a result of the training. 5) It is important to have
            clear arrangements regarding coordination and information
            sharing among donors of the program. 6) The Bank failed to
            provide adequate resources to ensure proper project
            supervision and implementation assistance. 7) Development
            objectives have to be realistically assessed. 8) Built-in
            flexibility is therefore an essential feature of such a
            project. 9) Accountability of service providers should be improved.
